Hornung, Sayers congratulate Damien Harris

Hornung, Sayers congratulate Damien Harris

Steve Jones, swjones1@courier-journal.com 9:53 p.m. EST December 17, 2014

2 CONNECT 5 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Damien Harris is one of the best running backs in the recent, if not entire, history of Kentucky high school football.

He received praise from some far more accomplished legends of the game on Wednesday.

Harris, the five-star player from Madison Southern High School and the nation's No. 1 running back, was gracious in accepting the Paul Hornung Award as the state's top football player. And before Hornung - the former Flaget High, Notre Dame and Green Bay Packers star - handed over the trophy at Big Spring Country Club, he handed Harris his cell phone.

Legendary Chicago Bears running back Gale Sayers was on the other end.

USA TODAY HIGH SCHOOL SPORTS

Q&amp;A: Damien Harris on UK's year, Hornung Award

"I said, 'Gale, wish this man good luck because this kid has a lot of the same ability you had,'" Hornung said. Afterward, Hornung told Harris, "I just want you to know that you talked to the best running back of all time."

Harris had to do a little asking to learn about the accomplishments of Hornung and Sayers, but he came away feeling humbled to be congratulated by those greats. Harris joins a who's who of Kentucky stars, including Shaun Alexander, Tim Couch, Michael Bush and DeVante Parker, who have won the Hornung Award, given by the Louisville Quarterback Club.

"A lot of people were telling me about this award, but I didn't know exactly who (Hornung) was," Harris said of the former Heisman Trophy winner. ". I had to look him up, but once I did, I understood the magnitude of the award."

He added: "It's definitely an honor to be in a club with such great players at a high standard of football. So I'm just really blessed and grateful to have this opportunity to win such a prestigious award."

Damien Harris is one of the best running backs in the recent, if not entire, history of Kentucky high school football. He received praise from some far more accomplished legends of the game on Wednesday. WHAS11

Harris, who was injured part of the season, needed only seven games to compile an award-winning campaign. He rushed for 1,474 yards and 23 touchdowns, averaging nearly 15 yards per carry, and solidified his status as a premier college prospect.

Harris still has the Under Armour All-American game in St. Petersburg, Fla., coming up on Jan. 2, but he is turning his attention toward his closely watched recruitment. He'll make his commitment on Jan. 9 and said he's still considering five schools: Kentucky, Alabama, Ohio State, Florida and Texas A&M.

Although that list remains at five, it's generally thought that things are coming down to the Wildcats, who want to make him the home-state hero in a rebuilding effort, and the Crimson Tide, which is looking for the next great back in a powerhouse program.

Harris said UK and Alabama are standing above the rest only "a little bit." That said, he also pointed out that Ohio State had another top back recently commit, that Florida has changed coaches and Texas A&M's staff hasn't talked to him much lately.

    Harris said his official visit to UK this past weekend which followed at least a half-dozen unofficial trips this year - was "just a great experience all the way around" as he got to bond with UK's other recruits and current players. In good news for the Cats, he said the recent departure of offensive coordinator Neal Brown his lead recruiter to Troy "doesn't really affect me very much because I'm very close with a lot of the coaches on the staff."

    With Harris in attendance at most of the home games, UK's season started 5-1 following back-to-back 2-10 years. The Cats finished, however, with six straight losses. Did that slide hurt Harris' opinion of Kentucky?

    "Well, no, because you can't always determine a team's success by wins and losses," Harris said. "Every program is in different situations. Alabama, you know, they pride their season off winning and losing. Kentucky is about improvement. That's just two examples. (The Cats) are about improving as a school, and you can't go from winning two games to winning nine or 10 games (in one year), especially not in the SEC the hardest conference in America. How they finished the season didn't really affect me in any way."

    So what was Harris' main takeaway from the Cats' season?

    "They definitely improved, competing with SEC teams and almost beating the No. 1 team in the country (Mississippi State), beating South Carolina and getting their first SEC win in a while," he said. "They just played great. They did have some struggles, but they're a team in a rebuilding process, so you can't really expect them to be great all the time."

    Harris hopes to play in a pro-style offense in college and said Alabama definitely has that. He described UK's offense this year as "kind of pro-style with a little bit of a spread approach."

    "They're both two styles of offense I'd be good at playing in," he said.

    1993: Shaun Alexander, Boone County

    1994: Chris Redman, Male

    1995: Tim Couch, Leslie County

    1996: Tony Driver, Male

    1997: Dennis Johnson, Harrodsburg

    1998: Derek Smith, Highlands

    1999: Montrell Jones, Male

    2000: Jones

    2001: Michael Bush, Male

    2002: Bush, Brian Brohm, Trinity*

    2003: Brohm

    2004: Curtis Pulley, Hopkinsville

    2005: Micah Johnson, Fort Campbell

    2006: Doug Beaumont, Male

    2007 Sam Robey, Trinity and Dave Ulinski, Manual*

    2008: Deuce Finch, St. Xavier

    2009: Austin Collinsworth, Highlands

    2010: Lamar Dawson, Boyle County and DeVante Parker, Ballard*

    2011: Patrick Towles, Highlands

    2012: James Quick, Trinity

    2013: Matt Elam, John Hardin

    2014: Damien Harris, Madison Southern

    *-denotes co-winners
